children.name: logical
children.definition: ideas, decisions etc that are logical are based on a series of facts or ideas connected in a correct and intelligent way: có lý, hợp lý
examples: Your essay ought to take the form of a logical argument.
There is no logical reason for teaching boys and girls separately.
logically[adv] C2 một cách có lý
He explained his reasons clearly and logically.

children.name: take sth to its logical conclusion
examples: If you took the anti-war arguments to their logical conclusion, you would destroy all weapons.

children.name: it is logical to do sth
examples: If they did not leave until yesterday, then it is logical to assume that they will arrive some time tomorrow.

children.name: sound
children.definition: reasons, ideas, advice etc that are sound are logical and sensible, and it is easy to agree with them or believe that they are right:có lý
examples: The company offers sound financial advice to individuals and businesses.
Is recycling glass a sound idea?
There is no sound reason for the closure of this factory.

children.name: make sense
children.definition: an idea, decision or plan that makes sense is logical and easy to understand:hợp lý, hiểu được
examples: His arguments seem to make sense.

children.name: it makes sense for sth to happen
examples: It would make sense for the parents to be involved in this discussion.

children.name: rational
children.definition: a way of thinking, explanation, idea etc that is rational is very logical and is based on clear practical or scientific reasons, rather than on your feelings or wishes: hợp lý, lý trí
examples: We’re looking for someone with a rational approach to dealing with problems.
There must be some rational explanation for this apparently bizarre phenomenon.
There appears to be no rational motive for the attack.

children.name: reasonable
children.definition: sth that is reasonable seems to be logical and likely to be true because of what you know of the situation: có lý, hợp lý
examples: It is a reasonable assumption that she knew him well, as she had the keys to his house.
Given that the patient smokes 50 cigarettes a day, it would be reasonable to assume there is some lung damage.

children.name: reasoned
children.definition: a reasoned way of thinking about sth is logical and has been thought about very carefully: hợp lý
examples: ▪ We must have an informed and reasoned debate of the moral issues involved.
▪ It became clear that calm, reasoned arguments were not working in this volatile situation.

children.name: well-thought-out
children.definition: a well-thought-out plan or way of doing sth is carefully and logically planned:được cân nhắc kỹ
examples: Before we can apply for funding, we must have strong, well-thought-out proposals.

children.name: coherent
children.definition: words, thoughts or ideas that are coherent are arranged in an order that makes them easy to understand: mạch lạc chặt chẽ
examples: He couldn’t give a coherent account of what he’d been doing that night.
His book contains a coherent argument in favour of economic change.
The three years of the course are planned as a coherent whole.

children.name: a coherent account of the incident
hang together
children.definition: informalif a piece of writing or an explanation hangs together, it is easy to understand because its parts are connected in a way that seems natural and logical: mạch lạc
examples: Her story doesn’t hang together very well.

children.name: add up
children.definition: informalif a set of facts add up, they are logically connected so they provide a reasonable explanation of a situation :có nghĩa, có lý
examples: I can see now that George was planning this all along - it all adds up.

children.name: able to think in a logical way
logical
children.definition: sb who is logical is good at thinking in a very careful, clear, and organized way:suy nghĩ logic
examples: Joe’s very sharp and logical when it comes to money matters.
She’s a clear and logical thinker.
Men often accuse women of not being logical.

children.name: rational
children.definition: sb who is rational is able to think clearly and logically without letting their emotions influence their decision or opinions: lý trí
examples: How can a rational man be taken in by these arguments?
Let’s try and discuss this like two rational human beings.
Culley was quite rational at the time of her baby’s death.

children.name: logic
children.definition: a way of thinking about something that seems correct and reasonable, or a set of sensible reasons for doing sth :

children.name: understand/see sb’s logic
examples: I could not understand the logic of her actions.

children.name: follow sb’s logic
children.definition: to use someone’s logic in an activity or situation
examples: Following this logic, none of these distressing conditions would be considered 'real' illnesses.

children.name: use/apply logic
examples: Why do we not apply the same logic in the way we treat animals?

children.name: accept sb’s logic
children.definition: agree that a reason is correct
examples: The government should accept this logic and exempt all students from paying the tax.

children.name: defy logic
children.definition: to not be reasonable
examples: It defies logic to import food that we can grow more easily and cheaply here.

children.name: logic suggests something
children.definition: used when you want to argue that something is reasonable
examples: Logic suggests that if the air is warmer, more water evaporates.

children.name: logic dictates something
children.definition: used to say that something will definitely happen because of logic
examples: Logic dictates that poorer people will be more affected by the rise in inflation.

children.name: commercial/industrial/economic etc logic
examples: Reducing your carbon footprint is also backed by good economic logic.

children.name: internal logic
children.definition: logic that seems sensible within a particular activity or situation
examples: Each major religion has its own internal logic.

children.name: underlying logic
children.definition: logic that is important, but not easily noticed
examples: These word lists show students the underlying logic of English spelling.

children.name: inexorable logicformal
children.definition: logic in which one thing leads to another in a way that cannot be avoided
examples: By the inexorable logic of war, the bombings provoked an even stronger response.

children.name: impeccable logic
children.definition: very good logic
examples: He worked out, with impeccable logic, that the best thing to do would be to cooperate.

children.name: a certain logic
children.definition: used when something does not seem sensible, but there are understandable reasons for it
examples: With a certain logic, the child said that ‘ten and one’ would be the next number after ten.

children.name: logic behind
examples: The logic behind this statement is faulty.

children.name: logic of
examples: What’s the logic of your argument?

children.name: accept/follow/see sb’s logic
examples: It’s easy to understand his logic.
There isa certain logicin their choice of architect.

children.name: commercial/industrial/economic logic
examples: Commercial logic has forced the two parts of the company closer together.

children.name: reasoning
children.definition: a logical way of thinking, used especially to make decisions or to explain why sth happened: lập luận, lý lẽ,
examples: Although I understood her reasoning, I did not agree with her decision.

children.name: line of reasoningthe reasoning someone has used to find an answer, explanation etc for a particular problem
examples: I found it hard to follow his line of reasoning.

children.name: reasoning behind
examples: The architect was asked to explain the reasoning behind his new design.
What is the reasoning behind this decision?

children.name: illogical
children.definition: not sensible or reasonableOPP logical: vô lý
examples: Listen to your child’s worries and fears, however illogical they may seem.
I found some of his arguments totally illogical.
illogical and unreasonable fear
it is illogical to do sth
It is illogical to sell stocks and shares when their value is low.
Because we do not know what death is, it is illogical to fear it.
It is illogical to assume you can do the work of three people.

children.name: irrational
children.definition: sth sb says or does that is irrational is not logical and often seems slightly crazy, especially because it is based only on emotions: không lý trí
examples: His behaviour can be somewhat irrational at times.
She struggled to overcome her irrational fear of the dark.

children.name: an irrational fear of flying
examples: He’s becoming increasingly irrational.

children.name: make no sense
children.definition: not make sense/ sth that does not make sense, especially sb’s behaviour, is very difficult to understand because there seems to be no logical reason for it: không có lý, không hiểu nổi
examples: I can’t understand why she’s so annoyed -- it doesn’t make sense.
Increasing interest rates now would make no sense at all.

children.name: it makes no sense to do sth
examples: It makes no sense to invest more money in a project that is so obviously a failure.

children.name: not hold water
children.definition: informalan explanation that does not hold water does not seem logical and can be easily criticized or proved to be incorrect:không vững, không đứng vững được
examples: His account of events simply doesn’t hold water.

children.name: not stand up
children.definition: an explanation that does not stand up does not seem logical and can be easily criticized or proved to be incorrect:không vững
examples: He might be able to convince his lawyer that he’s telling the truth, but his story won’t stand up in court.

children.name: not stand up to criticism/analysis etc
examples: It’s an interesting theory, but I don’t think it will stand up to close examination.

children.name: not add up
children.definition: informal if a set of facts or statements do not add up, they do not seem to be logically connected, even though it is difficult to say why: vô lý
examples: Why had she left the note? It just didn’t add up.
There were a few things in his story that didn’t add up.

children.name: based on theory rather than experience
theoretical
children.definition: a theoretical situation or condition could exist but does not really existSYN hypothetical:
examples: Equality between men and women in our society is still only theoretical.
theoretically[sentence adv] C2according to a scientific idea that has not been proven to be true in a practical waySYN hypothetically:
It is theoretically possible for computers to be programmed to think like humans.

children.name: a theoretical risk of an explosion
in theory
children.definition: if sth is possible in theory, it should be possible, but often it does not happen in that way
examples: In theory, the journey ought to take three hours, but in practice it usually takes four because of roadworks.
In theory, everyone will have to pay the new tax.

children.name: hypothetical
children.definition: based on a situation that is not real, but that might happen : giả thuyết

children.name: hypothetical situation/example/question
examples: Brennan brought up a hypothetical case to make his point.
The question ispurely hypothetical.

children.name: a hypothetical example/situation
examples: This is all very hypothetical but supposing Jackie got the job, how would that affect you?

children.name: theoretical
children.definition: relating to the study of ideas, especially scientific ideas, rather than with practical uses of the ideas or practical experience →practical,applied: lý thuyết
examples: theoretical physics
Aristotle’s theoretical model of the universe
She has theoretical knowledge of teaching, but no practical experience.
theoretically[sentence adv] C2used to say what is supposed to be true in a particular situation, especially when the opposite is trueOPP in practice:
Theoretically, Damian’s the boss, but I coordinate the team on a day-to-day basis.

children.name: a situation or statement with two opposite ideas
paradox
children.definition: a statement or situation that contains two opposite ideas or parts, so that it seems strange that they could both be true at the same time: nghịch lí
examples: There’s a paradox in the fact that although we’re living longer than ever before, people are more obsessed with health issues than they ever were
paradoxical[adj] C2
Raising interest rates seems a paradoxical way of bringing down inflation.
paradoxically[adv]
Paradoxically, it’s the parents who try to protect their children most who can make them unable to cope with risky situations on their own.

children.name: unrealistic
children.definition: unrealistic ideas or hopes are not reasonable or sensible : phi thực tế
examples: I think these sales forecasts are unrealistic, considering how slow sales are at present.
Some parents have totallyunrealistic expectationsof teachers.

children.name: it is unrealistic to do sth
examples: It is unrealistic to expect these changes to happen overnight.
It's unrealistic to expect an answer before next week.
